Own-Price Elasticity of Demand
Own-price elasticity is a measure of the responsiveness of the quantity demanded to
a change in price. It is calculated as the ratio of the percentage change in quantity
demanded to a percentage change in price. When quantity demanded is very responsive
to a change in price, we say demand is elastic; when quantity demanded is not very
responsive to a change in price, we say that demand is inelastic. In Figure 1, we
illustrate the most extreme cases: perfectly elastic demand (at any higher price, quantity
demanded decreases to zero) and perfectly inelastic demand (a change in price has no
effect on quantity demanded).
